name: Pablo
text:
Isabel: Okay, so it's Isabel, and I'm here with Pablo.
 
 
   Pablo: Yes.
 
 
   Isabel: Can you tell me a bit about how old you were when you migrated,
   what the reasons were?
 
 
   Pablo: I was five years old, and the reason was because my Dad died when I
   was five, so my Mom decided to go to the States and work for a better life.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah.
 
 
   Pablo: So, I think that's why. I don’t know. What else?
 
 
   Isabel: Did you end up crossing the border or did you get a visa?
 
 
   Pablo: I actually used somebody else's papers, somebody else's documents.
 
 
   Isabel: Mhm [affirmative].
 
 
   Pablo: So I basically...
 
 
   Isabel: That's how you got over?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. I didn't cross the border or anything.
 
 
   Isabel: Do you remember your first moments in the US?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. I remember that this lady, the one that took me over there,
   she just told me to go to sleep so I wouldn't have to talk or anything. And
   I was like, "Okay." It wasn't hard for me to go to sleep, so I just fell
   asleep. And when I woke up, I was over there, everything was so different.
   So I was surprised... I don't know. I felt good.
 
 
   Isabel: What was different?
 
 
   Pablo: I mean, you can see everything... It was just… the city was just
   more clean, or I don't know, it's just a lot of different stuff. The stores
   and buildings and everything was just different.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah. A lot of people mentioned the air or the smell, even, was
   different.
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: And where did you end up living when you moved to the US?
 
 
   Pablo: I grew up in Georgia. Before that, when I crossed over there, I
   stayed in Houston for like two months. And then we also went to Florida for
   another like two months.
 
 
   Isabel: And then Houston was where you put in your roots a bit. And what
   was it like growing up in Houston? Did you know you were undocumented?
 
 
   Pablo: I did know. I mean, pretty much I grew up in Georgia...
 
 
   Isabel: Oh, sorry, Georgia.
 
 
   Pablo: At the beginning it was hard, going to school and not speaking
   English, everybody making fun of you, and it was hard. But then after a
   while you get used to it, and get the hang of it, started making friends
   and stuff.
 
 
   Isabel: Did you take ESL classes?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, I did.
 
 
   Isabel: What were those like?
 
 
   Pablo: They were boring.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah.
 
 
   Pablo: But they were cool because we were all Hispanic people, so it felt
   good, than just being with a bunch of Americans. They didn't speak English
   that well, so it was better to be with our ESL team.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah. More comfortable probably. Did you like school? Did you like
   any particular teachers, or not really for you?
 
 
   Pablo: Not really. Yeah, I didn't really like school, honestly.
 
 
   Isabel: What did you like outside of school?
 
 
   Pablo: I liked playing soccer, I liked playing soccer, but there's a lot of
   stuff going out there that gets your attention, all this partying and
   stuff. So yeah, I pretty much got into all that.
 
 
   Isabel: How old were you when you got into all that?
 
 
   Pablo: I was 14 when I started hanging out with those friends and-
 
 
   Isabel: Were these friends just partying or were they also doing illegal
   activities?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, they were actually doing illegal activities, also. I got
   involved. I mean, I lived right there.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah. Were these gangs or just casual groups?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. Yeah, some of them. Well actually, a few of my cousins they
   were already involved in gangs, so it was pretty easy for me to get used to
   that.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah, slip into that lifestyle, I bet.
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: And that was when you were around 14 years old?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: So did you stop playing soccer then, around there?
 
 
   Pablo: Mm-hmm (affirmative). I stopped playing soccer, then I left school
   When I was 15 I dropped out of school.
 
 
   Isabel: What grade was that?
 
 
   Pablo: That was in eighth grade, middle school, the last grade.
 
 
   Isabel: Did your parents have anything to say about that or were they
   not...?
 
 
   Pablo: My mom she did not really say anything about that because I actually
   told her that I wanted to get a job because I was not doing good in school.
   So she was like, "Okay, well, if you're going to do better by having a job,
   then just get a job. I'll help you get a job." Then she basically talked to
   one of her friends that she had, and he helped me to get a job. So I
   started working when I was 15. It was at a carpet mill.
 
 
   Isabel: What did you do there?
 
 
   Pablo: We would get, how do you call them, big rolls of carpet? We would
   just have machines to cut them in different sizes and...
 
 
   Isabel: Big machines?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: Were they dangerous?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, because they're cutting machines and...
 
 
   Isabel: Did they know you were 15? Or did you have to say?
 
 
   Pablo: They didn't know I was 15 because I was obviously using a fake ID.
   So I was 15, but on that fake ID, I would supposedly be 27.
 
 
   Isabel: Oh, wow.
 
 
   Pablo: I mean they knew, but that's just how it is.
 
 
   Isabel: Did you make any friends at work?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, I did have a lot of friends at work. Most of them just
   Hispanic people.
 
 
   Isabel: Around your age, too?
 
 
   Pablo: A few, like one or two that were my age. But I think I was the
   youngest one.
 
 
   Isabel: And this time you were also... Were you in the gang or just
   affiliated around it?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, I was in the gang.
 
 
   Isabel: In the gang as well?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: And what do you think drew you to that? Because one thing my
   professor's interested in is the sort of factors that draw or bring kids
   into gangs and that kind of activity, away from school and stuff, what the
   trends are. What was it in your case?
 
 
   Pablo: In my case, where I grew up, we did have a few different cliques
   that were not getting along together. So it was basically... How can I say?
   Just wanted everybody to know you, everybody to respect you, and know that
   you were part of the best team, or best gang, whatever, that's it.
 
 
   Isabel: So would you say it was a pride thing or more protection?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, it's a pride thing. It's a pride thing. Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah, especially if you had family members who were already in it.
   That's on top of being sort of like brothers through that. You're also
   already by blood, as well.
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah. So you were working and also doing this when you weren't
   working. So you were doing both simultaneously?
 
 
   Pablo: When I started working, I didn't get to hang around with them that
   much, that’s when I didn't used to work, that’s when I was in school. But
   there was times, for example, on the weekends and everything, every weekend
   there would be someone there to pick me up and "You know what? Let's go do
   this and that."
 
 
   Isabel: What was this and that?
 
 
   Pablo: We would just go banging. We would go to the clubs, nightclubs, we
   would go to the bars, we would go to the parks. And if you see a rival
   gang, then we would just... Like we say, hit them up.
 
 
   Isabel: Hit them up. Is that just start a fight?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. Basically, yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: And that was from 15 years old to...
 
 
   Pablo: To like 17, 18.
 
 
   Isabel: To 17. And then what happened when you were 17 or 18?
 
 
   Pablo: Well, I kind of came down a little bit.
 
 
   Isabel: Why was that?
 
 
   Pablo: I got with a girl. She came to live with me. I dedicated more time
   to her. She didn't really let me go out that much because she knew what I
   was doing. Basically, it was for her that I came down.
 
 
   Isabel: Did you have a child with her or anything?
 
 
   Pablo: No. Well she got pregnant one time, something went wrong, and she
   lost it.
 
 
   Isabel: Like a miscarriage?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. She had a miscarriage.
 
 
   Isabel: Did you want the baby?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, no I did want the baby. Yeah. It was messed up.
 
 
   Isabel: I'm sorry. I know, that's difficult.
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: So then how old were you when you left the US, or how did you leave
   the US?
 
 
   Pablo: I was 22. I was 22. 21 or 22.
 
 
   Isabel: What led to you leaving the US? What happened?
 
 
   Pablo: Well, I got deported.
 
 
   Isabel: Oh, you were deported?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: What were the events leading up to deportation? What caused it?
 
 
   Pablo: I was driving without a license.
 
 
   Isabel: Driving without a license. And did they have any other record of
   you because of your affiliation when you were younger with gangs, or...?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, gang-related.
 
 
   Isabel: Were you ever stopped by the police before that?
 
 
   Pablo: No.
 
 
   Isabel: So this was your first infraction or whatever you want to call it,
   driving without a license. So were you taken in by the police? How were you
   treated? What happened?
 
 
   Pablo: I was taken in by the police and then the ICE officer would come
   visit county jail every weekend. They would take care of all illegal
   people, make you sign your deportation.
 
 
   Isabel: So did they present you of your rights, or what happened?
 
 
   Pablo: No, they just made me sign deportation. They didn't provide me with
   any rights or anything. It was just like, "You're going to sign this so you
   can get deported." Because I had gotten arrested before. I was in county,
   also. I was 17 by then.
 
 
   Isabel: Why were you arrested that time?
 
 
   Pablo: Because I had an issue with my girlfriend. Her mom, she actually
   called the cops on me because we were fighting and stuff, so yeah they took
   me to jail.
 
 
   Isabel: They got like physical, then? Mom called the cops, and you were
   taken to jail at 17?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: Okay. So then they had you in the system beforehand?
 
 
   Pablo: Yes.
 
 
   Isabel: And then when you were arrested for driving without a license, they
   looked that up. You weren't given the chance to fight your case or
   anything?
 
 
   Pablo: Yes, I was, but I didn't want to.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah. Why was that? Just didn't want to spend that much time in
   detention or anything?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. Yeah, because I would see a lot of people that they'd be
   fighting their case and they would be in jail for a year. And then after
   that, they'd still get deported. So might as well just deport me right
   away. I don't want to spend a lot of time just here, so that at the end you
   can just go and deport me anyways.
 
 
   Isabel: Right. Were you still like with your girlfriend?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: And your daughter?
 
 
   Pablo: With what?
 
 
   Isabel: Oh, sorry, you didn't have a child. I'm sorry. [inaudible 00:12:22]
   sensitive. So you were still with your girlfriend at the time.
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: And then, soon you're deported. Was that difficult to leave her?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, it was. She used to tell me that she wanted to come down here
   with me, but I was like... I was struggling over here, and it was not easy.
   So, I told her, "You know what? I don't think it's a good idea. Because
   things are different, and you're not going to like it, and I don't want to
   tell you, 'Yes, come on over here and we're going to be fine.' And then
   what if you don't like it and then you get mad and you're going to be like,
   'It's your fault I came over here.'" I didn't want none of that.
 
 
   Isabel: It's a big risk.
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: Was she also undocumented?
 
 
   Pablo: Yes.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah, so if she came, she would have to probably stay as well.
   Could you tell me about, you said it was difficult reintegrating. Can you
   tell me a bit about your deportation? How you were deported and then what
   it was like being in Mexico, because again, it's almost like a new country.
   You spent so much time in the US. Just how is reintegrating into Mexican
   society?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. Well, it is kind of difficult, because it was hard for me to
   get a job at first, because I didn't have any documents or any papers or
   anything. And my parents wouldn't help me, either because I was... I used
   to dress weird.
 
 
   Isabel: Weird?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. They always tell me I got a mean face. I don't know why, but
   everybody always tells me that. And since I used to dress baggy, they would
   look at me like…
 
 
   Isabel: Oh, thinking that you were becoming dangerous or something, or
   untrustworthy?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: Because we've talked to a lot of people who have had similar
   experiences, were affiliated or part of gangs in the US and then were like,
   "Okay, I want a second chance. I want to get the job here, do different
   things." And then maybe because of their tattoos and the way they present
   themselves, are then stereotyped as that way here, as well. So that was a
   bit of your experience?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: So when you were reintegrating back, was it difficult? What were
   some of the biggest challenges finding a job, being separated from your
   girlfriend?
 
 
   Pablo: Well, being separated from my mom, because actually I was over there
   with my mom and my mom's still over there. She's still living over there in
   Georgia.
 
 
   Isabel: And you're close with your mom?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah. We talk a lot.
 
 
   Isabel: Do you talk a lot now?
 
 
   Pablo: By the phone, yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: Does she check in with you?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: What do you talk about? Just anything?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, just how she's doing, how I'm doing, how things are over here,
   how things are over there. Kids over there, my little brothers and sisters.
   How they’re doing.
 
 
   Isabel: So pretty much your whole family is back in the US.
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: And how long have you been back in Mexico?
 
 
   Pablo: Six years now.
 
 
   Isabel: Six years. Do you feel like it's gotten easier since you first came
   here?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, a lot.
 
 
   Isabel: What's gotten better?
 
 
   Pablo: Well, I got a better job now and that's basically... I live on my
   own now, I can pay my own things. Then when I got here, I had to be moving
   around with my aunts and stuff.
 
 
   Isabel: With your family members.
 
 
   Pablo: With my family members, yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: So you had a bit of a support system, or... A little bit?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: Did you get any help from any other organizations or anything?
 
 
   Pablo: No.
 
 
   Isabel: Do you feel like you were treated differently here because you
   lived in the US for some time? Or do you feel different than other people
   here? Or no?
 
 
   Pablo: No. I don't feel different. I'm from here you know. I mean what gets
   me kind of upset is like you know, like I've seen people around here, some
   guys that I work with, they grew up in the US, and when they come here,
   they be like, "Hey, where you from?" They try to bring like the stuff from
   over there, over here. For example, I had some guys the other day come up
   to me and they're like, "Where you from?" Because they come with the... How
   can I say it?
 
 
   Pablo: When you're in a gang in the US, you come up to see another gang
   member, you're like, "Where you from?" And then you start all that stuff,
   you know. That upsets me kind of because we're in Mexico, and we're
   Mexican. I seen some people here, they'll be like, "Ah, Well, I'm from
   Chicago, or I'm from LA or..." Like that. I'm going to be like, “well then
   why are you here if you were from Chicago or if you were from LA? Or
   whatever you say you're from, you wouldn't be here, you know” I don't like
   saying that, because like I said, I do see people here that be like that.
   "Well, I come from Chicago or I come from..."
 
 
   Pablo: Okay, you come from over there, you grew up over there. But I mean,
   you're not even from over there. You're from here. I mean, that's something
   that just I don't...
 
 
   Isabel: So do you feel like you're more in touch with your Mexican roots or
   identity here than some other people you know coming in?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah, yeah. I mean, if somebody comes up to me and be like, "Where
   you from?" I'm not going to be like, "Well I'm from Georgia." No, I'm from
   here. I was born here. I lived over there, but that's it.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah. Some people will say like, "Oh, well, you're either like too
   American to be Mexican or too Mexican to be American." What's your response
   to that?
 
 
   Pablo: I don't think I have a response to that. I'm just Mexican, that's
   it.
 
 
   Isabel: That's who I am.
 
 
   Pablo: Pretty much.
 
 
   Isabel: If you were in the US still, what do you think you'd be doing?
 
 
   Pablo: Working.
 
 
   Isabel: Working. Do you know what job you'd want?
 
 
   Pablo: Well, you don't really have an option over there. You still illegal,
   so you got pretty much got to adapt to whatever there is. I don't mind. As
   long as I'm working, as long as I have a job, it don't really matter.
 
 
   Isabel: Nice. And what are your plans for, now that you're in Mexico? What
   do you hope to do?
 
 
   Pablo: I just want to keep working. I don't know. Just in the future, maybe
   get a house, have my Mom come over here.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah.
 
 
   Pablo: That's it.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah. Be with your mother. Nice. Well, is there anything else you'd
   want people to know or experiences you should share?
 
 
   Pablo: No, I think that's about it. It is pretty hard. And once you get
   deported, especially when you get deported, when you come by your own
   decision, you know, you're good. But when you get deported and you just get
   arrested with no money in your pocket and then they let you out like that.
   And it is pretty hard because Mexico is dangerous. There's a lot of things
   that can happen to you and stuff. I'm glad I made it. I'm glad I'm here
   now. I'm glad I got a job. I'm not into that much trouble anymore. I have
   my kid.
 
 
   Isabel: And now you have a child here?
 
 
   Pablo: Yeah.
 
 
   Isabel: How old is your kid here?
 
 
   Pablo: He's two.
 
 
   Isabel: Two. Are there any values or things that you feel like you want
   your kid to have, or what do you hope?
 
 
   Pablo: Yes, I do want my kid to- I want him to in the future, grow up,
   study as much as he can, get a career, be someone not like me. I want him
   to --That's why I only want one, so I can give him everything. I don't want
   any more kids. I mean, I'm not going to be able to give him everything.
   Might as well just keep one and give him all that I can.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah, absolutely. Do you think you'd ever want your kid to go to
   the US and visit your family?
 
 
   Pablo: Of course, yes.
 
 
   Isabel: Do any education in the US, do everything here, or...?
 
 
   Pablo: No. I mean, I think he can do it here. I don't think there's no need
   for you to go to US. You can be someone here. You can study here, you can
   make a career.
 
 
   Isabel: Yeah.
 
 
   Pablo: You don't necessarily need to go somewhere else. In the future, you
   never know if there would be an opportunity. I'm not going to stop him
   from... I don't know. There's a chance that in the future he decides that
   he wants to go over somewhere else or he wants... It just depends on him.
   I'm just going to support him through whatever he wants to do. As long as
   it's something good, I'm always going to just be there and support him.
 
 
   Isabel: That's great. Yeah. That's what I wanted to hear from you, just
   your own personal experience, how you've changed because of it. That's a
   good note to end on.

My mom she did not really say anything about that because I actually

annotations.label: SENT

So she was like, "Okay, well, if you're going to do better by having a job,
   then just get a job.

annotations.label: SENT

annotations.label: SENT

Then she basically talked to
   one of her friends that she had, and he helped me to get a job.

   started working when I was 15.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Just wanted everybody to know you, everybody to respect you, and know that
   you were part of the best team, or best gang, whatever, that's it.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So would you say it was a pride thing or more protection?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Yeah, especially if you had family members who were already in it

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: That's on top of being sort of like brothers through that.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
You're also
   already by blood, as well.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So you were working and also doing this

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So you were doing both simultaneously?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
When I started working, I didn't get to hang around with them that
   much, that’s when I didn't used to work, that’s when I was in school.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
But
   there was times, for example, on the weekends and everything, every weekend
   there would be someone there to pick me up and "You know what? Let's go do
   this and that."
 
 
   Isabel: What was this and that?
 
 
   Pablo:

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
We would go to the clubs, nightclubs, we
   would go to the bars, we would go to the parks.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
And if you see a rival
   gang, then we would just...

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Like we say, hit them up.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Is that just start a fight?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And that was from 15 years old to...

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And then what happened when you were 17 or 18?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Well, I kind of came down a little bit.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: She came to live with me.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I dedicated more time
   to her.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
She didn't really let me go out that much because she knew what I
   was doing.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Basically, it was for her that I came down.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Did you have a child with her or anything?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Well she got pregnant one time, something went wrong, and

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Yeah, no I did want the baby.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
So then how old were you when you left the US, or how did you leave
   the US?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: What led to you leaving the US?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: What were the events leading up to deportation?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I was driving without a license.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
And did they have any other record of
   you because of your affiliation when you were younger with gangs, or...?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Were you ever stopped by the police before that?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
So this was your first infraction or whatever you want to call it,
   driving without a license.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So were you taken in by the police?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I was taken in by the police and then the ICE officer would come

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
They would take care of all illegal
   people, make you sign your deportation.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So did they present you of your rights, or what happened?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: No, they just made me sign deportation.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
They didn't provide me with
   any rights or anything.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
It was just like, "You're going to sign this so you
   can get deported."

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Because I had gotten arrested before.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Why were you arrested that time?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Pablo: Because I had an issue with my girlfriend.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Her mom, she actually
   called the cops on me because we were fighting and stuff, so yeah they took
   me to jail.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Mom called the cops, and you were
   taken to jail at 17?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So then they had you in the system beforehand?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And then when you were arrested for driving without a license

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
You weren't given the chance to fight your case or
   anything?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Yes, I was, but I didn't want to.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Just didn't want to spend that much time in
   detention or anything?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Yeah, because I would see a lot of people that they'd be
   fighting their case and they would be in jail for a year.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
And then after
   that, they'd still get deported.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
So might as well just deport me right
   away.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I don't want to spend a lot of time just here,

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
so that at the end you
   can just go and deport me anyways.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Were you still like with your girlfriend?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Oh, sorry, you didn't have a child.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So you were still with your girlfriend at the time.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Was that difficult to leave her?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
She used to tell me that she wanted to come down here
   with me, but I was like...

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I was struggling over here, and it was not easy.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So, I told her, "You know what?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I don't think it's a good idea.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Because
   things are different, and you're not going to like it, and I don't want to
   tell you, 'Yes, come on over here and we're going to be fine.'

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
And then
   what if you don't like it and then you get mad and you're going to be like,

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: 'It's your fault I came over here.'"

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I didn't want none of that.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Yeah, so if she came, she would have to probably stay as well.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Could you tell me about, you said it was difficult reintegrating.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Can you
   tell me a bit about your deportation?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
How you were deported and then what
   it was like being in Mexico, because again, it's almost like a new country.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: You spent so much time in the US.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Just how is reintegrating into Mexican
   society?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Well, it is kind of difficult, because it was hard for me to
   get a job at first, because I didn't have any documents or any papers or
   anything.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And my parents wouldn't help me, either because I was...

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: They always tell me I got a mean face.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I don't know why, but
   everybody always tells me that.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
And since I used to dress baggy, they would
   look at me like…

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Oh, thinking that you were becoming dangerous or something, or
   untrustworthy?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Because we've talked to a lot of people who have had similar
   experiences, were affiliated or part of gangs in the US and then were like,
   "Okay, I want a second chance.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I want to get the job here, do different
   things."

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
And then maybe because of their tattoos and the way they present
   themselves, are then stereotyped as that way here, as well.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
So that was a
   bit of your experience?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So when you were reintegrating back, was it difficult?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
What were
   some of the biggest challenges finding a job, being separated from your
   girlfriend?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Well, being separated from my mom, because actually I was over there
   with my mom and my mom's still over there.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
She's still living over there in
   Georgia.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And you're close with your mom?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Do you talk a lot now?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Does she check in with you?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Yeah, just how she's doing, how I'm doing, how things are over here,
   how things are over there.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Kids over there, my little brothers and sisters.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So pretty much your whole family is back in the US.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And how long have you been back in Mexico?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Do you feel like it's gotten easier since you first came
   here?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Well, I got a better job now and that's basically...

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I live on my
   own now, I can pay my own things.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Then when I got here, I had to be moving
   around with my aunts and stuff.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Pablo: With my family members, yeah.
 
 
   Isabel:

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: So you had a bit of a support system, or... A little bit?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Did you get any help from any other organizations or anything?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Do you feel like you were treated differently here because you
   lived in the US for some time?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Or do you feel different than other people
   here?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I mean what gets
   me kind of upset is like you know, like I've seen people around here, some
   guys that I work with, they grew up in the US, and when they come here,
   they be like, "Hey, where you from?"

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
They try to bring like the stuff from
   over there, over here.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
For example, I had some guys the other day come up
   to me and they're like, "Where you from?"

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
When you're in a gang in the US, you come up to see another gang
   member, you're like, "Where you from?"

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
And then you start all that stuff,
   you know.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
That upsets me kind of because we're in Mexico, and we're
   Mexican.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I seen some people here, they'll be like, "Ah, Well, I'm from
   Chicago, or I'm from LA or..."

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I'm going to be like, “well then
   why are you here if you were from Chicago or if you were from LA?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Or
   whatever you say you're from, you wouldn't be here, you know”

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I don't like
   saying that, because like I said, I do see people here that be like that.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: "Well, I come from Chicago or I come from..."

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Okay, you come from over there, you grew up over there.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
But I mean,
   you're not even from over there.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I mean, that's something
   that just I don't...

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
So do you feel like you're more in touch with your Mexican roots or
   identity here than some other people you know coming in?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I mean, if somebody comes up to me and be like, "Where
   you from?"

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I'm not going to be like, "Well I'm from Georgia."

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I lived over there, but that's it.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Some people will say like, "Oh, well, you're either like too
   American to be Mexican or too Mexican to be American."

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I don't think I have a response to that.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: If you were in the US still, what do you think you'd be doing?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Do you know what job you'd want?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Well, you don't really have an option over there.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
You still illegal,
   so you got pretty much got to adapt to whatever there is.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
As
   long as I'm working, as long as I have a job, it don't really matter.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And what are your plans for, now that you're in Mexico?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
What
   do you hope to do?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I just want to keep working.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Just in the future, maybe
   get a house, have my Mom come over here.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Well, is there anything else you'd
   want people to know or experiences you should share?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: No, I think that's about it.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
And once you get
   deported, especially when you get deported, when you come by your own
   decision, you know, you're good.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
But when you get deported and you just get
   arrested with no money in your pocket and then they let you out like that.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And it is pretty hard because Mexico is dangerous.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
There's a lot of things
   that can happen to you and stuff.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I'm glad I got a job.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I'm not into that much trouble anymore.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: And now you have a child here?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: How old is your kid here?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Are there any values or things that you feel like you want
   your kid to have, or what do you hope?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Yes, I do want my kid to-

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I want him to in the future, grow up,
   study as much as he can, get a career, be someone not like me.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: --That's why I only want one, so I can give him everything.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I don't want
   any more kids.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I mean, I'm not going to be able to give him everything.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Might as well just keep one and give him all that I can.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
Do you think you'd ever want your kid to go to
   the US and visit your family?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: Do any education in the US, do everything here, or...?

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I mean, I think he can do it here.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I don't think there's no need
   for you to go to US.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
You can study here, you can
   make a career.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: You don't necessarily need to go somewhere else.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
In the future, you
   never know if there would be an opportunity.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
I'm not going to stop him
   from...

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: There's a chance that in the future he decides

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
that
   he wants to go over somewhere else or he wants...

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text: I'm just going to support him through whatever he wants to do.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
As long as
   it's something good, I'm always going to just be there and support him.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
That's what I wanted to hear from you, just
   your own personal experience, how you've changed because of it.

annotations.label: SENT
annotations.text:
That's a
   good note to end on.
